projects.name: MotoGP
projects.background: After a particularly grueling development project at work, all I wanted to do was make something with my hands.  I was particularly drawn to the soothing, peaceful,and meticulous quality of cross-stitching. When I was young, I cross-stitched Christmas ornaments and pillow covers following store-bought patterns.  This time around I wanted to make my own patterns from photos.  As a means to this end I bit the bullet and decided to write an app.  While I was at it I wanted to learn a new technology: Javascript, CSS, & HTML.
projects.features: To start off the process the user chooses a photo to use as the base of the cross-stitch pattern.  From there the user can specify properties such as size and color count and also tweak the image.  Once the user is happy with her pattern on screen, she can then print out the pattern, step away from the computer, and start cross-stitching!
technologies: jQuery, Backbone, Underscore, jQuery UI, Handlebars

projects.name: blog bubbles
projects.background: After seeing Apple's RSS visualizer screensaver, I decided to implement a web app version of my own. I wanted to keep the same ambient movment of the Apple version but have multiple feeds visible at a time.  In order to extend the concept further, I tried to explore ways to visually convey each feed's characteristics such as number of posts and post dates.
projects.features: In the upper left, users can enter in the url of their desired feeds or select from a pre-filled drop down list.  The size and opacity of each post represnts how recently it was posted, with larger diameters mapping to more recent posts.  To refine the idea, posts made during the last 24 hours appear with a glow, drawing the user's attention.  When a feed is maximed, the posts are arranged chronologically around a circle, with the selcted post's content in the center.
